messageBody:
--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, John Cowan <cowan@...> wrote:
>
> Nicolas Aviles scripsit:
>
> > I am fascinated with the effort to make our life more difficult than
> > already is. When I think of simplifying English, I think of writing
> > "Linken" for Lincoln, "Wooster" for Worcester and "si" for see and sea,
>
> In that case, ssslist@yahoogroups.com is your proper home. (I'm there
> too.)
>
> > not to create a complete, foreign and awful alphabet to re-do the whole
> > thing.
>
> "Foreign"? Kingsley Read was English.
>
> > If we want to play "let's simplify English writing" why not to stick
> > with a simplify Latin-based alphabet. The WHOLE WORLD is using the
> > Latin alphabet to modify their non-latin written languages.
>
> Neither Cyrillic nor Arabic nor any of the Indic scripts is in any
> serious danger of displacement in ordinary life. People may use Latin
> script on the Internet, but even the need for that is disappearing with
> the prevalence of Unicode.
>
> > Even the chinese are thinking to drop the entire idiogram writing
> > system for a latin-based, easy writing.
>
> Hardly. Hanyu Pinyin provides an aid for learning Chinese writing in
> the early grades of school, but stop the average Chinese person and ask
> how much HYPY they remember.
>
> > In the meantime we are making the whole thing more difficult.
>
> Difficulty is in the eye of the beholder. The theory of the Read
> alphabets was and is to make a clean break from Latin and all its
> historical baggage.
>
> > Good luck.
>
> Thanks.
>
> --
> All Norstrilians knew what laughter was: John Cowan
> it was "pleasurable corrigible malfunction". cowan@...
> --Cordwainer Smith, Norstrilia
>
Actually. Hanyu Pinyin was initiated in China in 1956. Most of Chineses remember how to spell Hanyu Pinyin because they enter Chinese characters into electronic documents with Hanyu Pinyin most of the time. The function of Hanyu Pinyin is just like that of IPA.
